text: How about if you add them straight to the website, not load them from Google. With that site you can download them and embed: <https://google-webfonts-helper.herokuapp.com/fonts>

I appreciate the suggestion.  Since the theme is already using HubSpot's integration of Google Fonts, it's not something that can easily be done without ripping out a bunch through the theme settings (fields.json) file.

Hi, I have a client who has multiple themes (with templates) and folders (in the root) with literally hundreds of template files (some used, some not).
The folder structure is chaotic with poor naming conventions. My plan is to create (or modify 1 existing theme) with only the required number of template files with proper naming conventions and dynamic modules.

*My question is:* Is there a way to search for which templates are being used and by which landing page/blog post? Or is there a way to export a CVS with a list of page/post names and the template files being used?

<@U02UEA28Z9B> <@U02U98D9L07> Would you happen to know if there’s a better way?

unfortunately that is the only way because if a user selects a font in a module, Google Fonts get loaded and Google sends the IP-Adress ( which is the actual violation of the law for everyone wondering)
the only way I know to check is to manually click each file to check for dependents, following to see if anyone knows a better way!

Thank you Jennifer, this is my understanding also. Right-click each file and select dependents (which opening in a new Design Manager tab), click more details, then click back to view the file tree and start again.
There are 300 template across 9 themes and folders (the client has just been duplicating templates for over 400 landing pages over the years).
Hopefully there’ a better way…
oh wow....how many LPs do they have live?

Of these, theres around 130 set to draft/archive, the rest are published :tired_face:.
Hoping to get a list together, so we can filter these down to what’s current and relevant.

I was going to suggest it might be easier to set up a new theme and start migrating the live content over so you wouldn't really have to worry about the old content so much, but that sounds equally as painful!
Thanks for your suggestion, this is in line with my plan, if/when I find a solution, otherwise it’ll need to be done manually.
still hoping someone else knows a better way, will keep my fingers crossed for you!
